channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: What happens when Cambodia graduates from aid but isn’t self-sustaining?
item.description: Cambodia’s “missing middle” means economic growth hasn’t yet produced the managers and technicians the country needs.

item.title: The New Wealth of Nations
item.description: How instrumental capital is reshaping the world.

item.title: Japan’s analog bureaucracy holds back a digital economy
item.description: Obtaining a criminal-record check should be a simple task, yet in Japan reveals a state capacity problem.

item.title: U.S. Suspends All Immigration Requests From 19 ‘High-Risk’ Countries
item.description: Critics say the mandate is evidence of the Trump administration’s xenophobic policies.

item.title: U.S. Issues Sweeping Immigration Crackdown on 19 Countries
item.description: Critics say the mandate is evidence of the Trump administration’s xenophobic policies.

item.title: A Chinese firm attempts to bring a rocket stage back to Earth
item.description: It fails, but the launch suggests the Americans may soon have real competition

item.title: Mali’s Junta Is the Architect of Its Own Disasters
item.description: Blaming foreign intervention is easy—but mistaken.

item.title: Putin Heads to New Delhi
item.description: The visit comes at a somewhat precarious moment for India-Russia relations.

item.title: China’s Military Machine Shouldn’t Run on American Chips
item.description: The GAIN AI Act would have given U.S. buyers priority in the global AI race.

item.title: Was Guinea-Bissau’s Coup a Sham?
item.description: Major African politicians are claiming that Africa’s latest putsch was staged.

item.title: Stockholm is Europe’s new capital of capital
item.description: And with Sweden embarking on a borrowing spree, it is a bond trader’s paradise

item.title: Enough dithering. Europe must pay to save Ukraine
item.description: America will not. Europe’s security depends on agreeing how to

item.title: Which Kevin Hassett would lead the Federal Reserve?
item.description: He was once a right-of-centre tax expert. He has become a partisan hack

item.title: Why autism should not be treated as a single condition
item.description: A better understanding of its biology will lead to better interventions

item.title: Surging satellite numbers threaten to dazzle even space telescopes
item.description: Low-flying satellites can ruin astronomical observations

item.title: Netanyahu Wants a Never-Go-to-Jail Card
item.description: His bid for a pardon rests on the assumption that he’s irreplaceable.

item.title: Manias, Panics, and AI
item.description: By any metric, the US – and, by implication, the world – are now in the midst of an intense AI speculative boom. To assess whether all the investment pouring into the industry will build something useful, three questions must be addressed.

item.title: Will China Forcibly Boost Fertility?
item.description: China is widely expected to adopt a range of pronatalist policies in a bid to raise birth rates. But recent efforts to encourage women to have more babies will have short-lived effects, while coercive measures – such as bans on contraception and abortion – would trigger a public backlash and prove futile at best.

item.title: A survival guide for advisers to the powerful
item.description: From Nixon’s downfall to Merkel’s success, history offers hard lessons for those behind the throne.

item.title: From micro-dramas to video games, Chinese entertainment is booming
item.description: But how much slack will the Communist Party give creators?

item.title: Why Do US Congressional Leaders Keep Beating the Stock Market?
item.description: Members of Congress continue to trade individual stocks even as they shape legislative agendas and gain access to non-public information. New research sheds light on how political power affects financial outcomes and underscores the need for reforms that draw a firm line between public office and private profit.

item.title: Ukraine Can Only Rely on Itself
item.description: In any peace deal with Russia, security guarantees from outsiders won't guarantee much.

item.title: Ukraine’s Corruption Scandal Is Bad. But Exposing It Is a Win.
item.description: The fight was always for the independence of a country that can hold its powerful to account.

item.title: Netanyahu Is Still Following the Same Failed Gaza Strategy
item.description: Two years of war have brought tactical changes and immense suffering, but the political status quo endures.

item.title: Why does Donald Trump care about Honduras’s election?
item.description: His interventions have complicated matters

item.title: The Outlook for China-US Strategic Competition in 2026
item.description: Insights from Sarah M. Beran.

item.title: India’s defence-tech startups are thriving
item.description: The recent war with Pakistan has infused new energy into the sector

item.title: Lee Jae-myung’s Latest Policy Signals to North Korea
item.description: Lee has downgraded “denuclearization” as a goal. Will it be enough to attract interest from Pyongyang?

item.title: The Massive Costs of Anti-Immigration Policies
item.description: Even as aging populations leave the workforce and critical sectors scramble for talent, an anti-immigrant backlash is gathering force across much of the developed world. The result is a widening gap between economic fundamentals and policy choices that threatens long-term growth and prosperity.

item.title: Nokundi Bombing: A Threat to Pakistan’s Economic and Strategic Future
item.description: The attack targeted foreign nationals working on mining projects in Balochistan’s mineral-rich Chagai district.

item.title: As Cyclone Ditwah Recedes, Sri Lanka Confronts the Failures That Made a Disaster Inevitable
item.description: The total economic losses incurred are estimated to be around $6-$7 billion. This is more than the country’s foreign reserves.

item.title: A Return to Nuclear Testing Looks Inevitable. Here’s How to Manage It.
item.description: A limited test ban would set important guardrails to manage escalation among nuclear weapons states, particularly the U.S., Russia, and China.

item.title: Totalitarianism in China: Resurrected and Rejuvenated by Reform
item.description: Amid the political and economic changes of the early 2000s, it seemed unthinkable that China would revert back to Mao-era repression. But's that's exactly what happened.

item.title: One Year After Martial Law Debacle, South Korea’s New President Vows to Complete ‘Light Revolution’
item.description: In a special address, Lee Jae-myung expressed gratitude toward the citizens for their defense of Korean democracy.

item.title: Beyond Security Screening: What the National Guard Shooting Reveals About Afghan Resettlement
item.description: This incident is a reminder that individual acts of violence cannot be understood, or prevented, through security measures alone.

item.title: Building Global Africa
item.description: If the global community of people of African descent was fashioned into an integrated economy, it would present an unparalleled opportunity for deepening trade, mobilizing investment, and creating shared prosperity. All that has been lacking is a vision, and the political will to pursue it.

item.title: Three Cheers for the London Consensus
item.description: While the old Washington Consensus forced developing countries into an austerity straitjacket that inflicted enormous pain on ordinary people, a new set of principles from a multinational roster of economists organized by the London School of Economics offers a long-needed alternative. This time, politics isn't assumed away.

item.title: What Is the Filibuster Good For?
item.description: A term originally used to describe pirates is now synonymous with U.S. congressional dysfunction.

item.title: Foreign Aid With Chinese Characteristics
item.description: Where Beijing is—and isn’t—seeking influence.

item.title: The India Trump Made
item.description: Where American bullying is leading New Delhi.

item.title: Will Congress rein in Pete Hegseth and his boat-bombing campaign?
item.description: A deadly strike raises stark questions about America’s anti-drug war

item.title: Lawmakers demand answers about Pete Hegseth’s boat-bombing campaign
item.description: A deadly strike raises stark questions about America’s anti-drug war

item.title: Rethinking the Indo-Pacific as a single ocean system
item.description: The waters that connect the region matter more than the distances between its shores, and 2026 will test that principle.
